comment_text: I love learning,

Two years ago, I had to learn Linear Algebra as a core subject in my university. I hated it because neither did I know whats going on nor my professor put any effort to teach us properly and thats happened all it was online classes because of Covid- 19. I surely had to memorize tons of formula without understanding to pass this exam. Now I am glad I am finally understanding this concepts little by little. Thank you so much for this 😊😁

For me, your channel reopened the door to mathematics. I love maths! But I find it so difficult to ground. The difference between convention and fact was never taught to me, and so the grammar of mathematics overwhelmed me. I always found myself asking why this and not that.

Your videos don’t just offer animated diagrams, they use animation as visual proofs, you clearly state the convention of a system, and then display the facts visually within that convention. As a scientist, thinking about change geometrically allowed me to see graphical representation in wholly new ways.

This way of thinking helped me through my undergrad and masters, and will surely help me during my upcoming PhD, and Im currently reading mathematics books to push my learning further. But it all started here with you. Thank you.

I've noticed that you could take the collumns as vectors and the rows as coordinates, and when you define where are the vectors, you take each coordinate, and multiply it by it's basis vector, simmilarily in all the other multiplications.

For example, with the multiplication in the video:
(spoilers)


i j k i j k i j k -> each collumn corresponds to one basis vector
x coordinate | 0 -2 2 | | 0 1 2 | | 6 6 6 |
y coordinate | 5 1 5 | | 3 4 5 | = | 33 44 55 |
z coordinate | 1 4 -1 | | 6 7 8 | | 6 10 14 |

The intermediate steps (take into account that vector/coordinate thing i just described):


First, you take the once transformed i vector from the right matrix and transform it with the second transformation to get the final one:
i j k i i j k i
x | 0 -2 2 | | 0 | | 0 | | -2 | | 2 | | 6 |
y | 5 1 5 | | 3 | = 0 | 5 | + 3 | 1 | + 6 | 5 | = | 33 | -> the i collumn of the final awnser matrix
z | 1 4 -1 | | 6 | | 1 | | 4 | | -1 | | 6 |
Notice that for every coordinate in the i vector were transforming, we multiply it by it's basis vector from the first matrix.

Now do this for the rest it's hard too write that out like this and youtube will likely ruin this anyway.

ok so when you turn in a video game you are essentially rotating the whole environment around you in the opposite direction. To any fellow commenters, or even 3B1B if you see this, are the inferences with the "$$$" good/true/logical/okay?

L: a linear transformation
x: a vector in the normal basis with i, j, k (hats implied lol)
x = [a b c] but vertical like a column

x = a*i + b*j + c*k

We want to find L(x)...

L(x) = L(a*i + b*j + c*k)
$$$ = L(a*i) + L(b*j) + L(c*k) $$$
$$$ = aL(i) + bL(j) + cL(k) $$$

Also, if so, what would be the names of these properties? The first one is like the property that L is additive????? L(v) + L(w) = L(v + w)
The second one is that you can factor-out scalars L(a*v) = aL(v), but I have no idea what to call that one.

Hi Grant. I think the visualisation of which transformation is first algebraically by representing the multiplication of matrices as A*B should be A matrix is applied first and then B is applied second. I know it sounds crazy, but it works out right.

The thing is that if we were to transform the standard [ 1 , 0 , 0 ; 0 , 1 , 0 ; 0 , 0 , 1 ] matrix re-defining it's basis vectors we would take the Matrix B as the function (a matrix containing 3 vertical vectors - according to Computer Scientist Convention), and use each values of those vectors x,y,z to scale the basis vectors of the system A (standard system).

Taking that analogy to matrix multiplication, we would have already transformed standard matrix from the previous example (Matrix B), and we would like to re-define it again, by redefining the basis vectors, but this time the vectors of Matrix B. We would then take 3 vectors put together in a matrix C, to use the Bassi vectors of matrix B to create a composition final matrix.

So if we look at the order, the way the transformations were applied, would be first to the standard matrix A we would apply B and then C, which should be written:

A * B * C, and not the other way around, as we are basing the new system on the basis vectors of the previous one. While in the video you showed that operation for the inside is applied first, which would make the whole scaling of the basis vectors of the matrix on the left invalid, as the matrix on the left should be the one that we are applying the transformation to.

I was figuring it out watching the videos meticulously from the beginning of the series, and understanding each component. And then the analogy of a vector scaling a matrix simply being - scaling each of the basis vectors of the matrix on the left - and trying to apply that analogy to redefining (transforming) the already transformed matrix , just didn't work out in algebraic calculations
